cards.title: Powerhouse Geelong / Six storeys of street art by 350 artists
cards.rawTitle: Six storeys of street art by 350 artists

item.title: Australia's street art mecca: Powerhouse Geelong
item.trailText: The 3,000sqm Powerhouse in Geelong, Australia, empty since it was abandoned 45 years ago, has been transformed by the designs of more than 350 street artists, among them a giant piece by local hero Rone
item.standFirst: Over the past six months, Powerhouse Geelong in Victoria, Australia, has been transformed by the creative endeavours of more than 350 street artists. The 3,000sqm building, which sits on six acres facing Corio Bay, has been empty since it was abandoned 45 years ago. The six-storey-high walls, industrial staircases, windows and rooms have lately become a canvas for innovative designs, among them a giant piece by local hero Rone

displayImages.caption: Powerhouse Geelong is Australia’s largest indoor space where it’s legal to create ephemeral street art
displayImages.altText: The Powerhouse Geelong is Australia’s largest legal indoor space in which to create ephemeral street art
displayImages.cleanCaption: Powerhouse Geelong is Australia’s largest indoor space where it’s legal to create ephemeral street art

displayImages.caption: Pictured is a piece by Australian artist Adnate.
displayImages.altText: Pictured is a piece by Australian artist Adnate.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pictured is a piece by Australian artist Adnate.

displayImages.caption: Curator Ian Ballis and his team of volunteers began inviting artists to the Powerhouse in December 2014, and more than 350 have now completed work.
displayImages.altText: Curator Ian Ballis and his team of volunteers began inviting artists to the Powerhouse in December 2014, and more than 350 have now completed work.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Curator Ian Ballis and his team of volunteers began inviting artists to the Powerhouse in December 2014, and more than 350 have now completed work.

displayImages.caption: Using sprays, stencils and brushes, the artists have produced a bold of array of designs on concrete, glass, brick, metal ... just about any surface they can find.
displayImages.altText: Using sprays, stencils and brushes, the artists have produced a bold of array of designs on concrete, glass, brick, metal ... just about any surface they can find.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Using sprays, stencils and brushes, the artists have produced a bold of array of designs on concrete, glass, brick, metal ... just about any surface they can find.

displayImages.caption: Powerhouse Geelong is the realisation of a project which Ian Ballis, pictured, has been trying to get off the ground for 14 years. ‘It’s a space where the artists can finally have free reign, but it’s also educating a traditionally conservative population, changing the perception of; ‘if it comes out of a can it’s graffiti’,’ he said.
displayImages.altText: Powerhouse Geelong is the realisation of a project which Ian Ballis, pictured, has been trying to get off the ground for 14 years. “It’s a space where the artists can finally have free reign, but it’s also educating a traditionally conservative population, changing the perception of; ‘if it comes out of a can it’s graffiti’,” he said.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Powerhouse Geelong is the realisation of a project which Ian Ballis, pictured, has been trying to get off the ground for 14 years. ‘It’s a space where the artists can finally have free reign, but it’s also educating a traditionally conservative population, changing the perception of; ‘if it comes out of a can it’s graffiti’,’ he said.

displayImages.caption: Ian and his team took over in November 2014, removing 30 tons of rubbish that had built up over 45 years of abandonment. He invited 50 street artists to begin working in mid-December and his phone hasn’t stopped since. ‘We haven’t done this on a low budget, we’ve done it on no budget. I’ve put it together through hard work and assistance from volunteers and the community,’ he said.
displayImages.altText: Ian and his team took over in November, 2014, and removed 30 tons of rubbish that had built up over 45 years of abandonment. He invited 50 street artists to begin working in mid December, and his phone hasn’t stopped since. “We haven’t done this on a low budget, we’ve done it on no budget. We’ve come here with no money and I’ve put it together through hard work and assistance from volunteers and the community,” he said.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ian and his team took over in November 2014, removing 30 tons of rubbish that had built up over 45 years of abandonment. He invited 50 street artists to begin working in mid-December and his phone hasn’t stopped since. ‘We haven’t done this on a low budget, we’ve done it on no budget. I’ve put it together through hard work and assistance from volunteers and the community,’ he said.

displayImages.caption: The street art community and local government are two groups who rarely see eye to eye, but Ian has so far managed to make the project work.
displayImages.altText: The street art community and local government are two groups who rarely see eye to eye, but Ian has so far mana
displayImages.cleanCaption: The street art community and local government are two groups who rarely see eye to eye, but Ian has so far managed to make the project work.

displayImages.caption: The Powerhouse opened its doors to the public earlier this year and has welcomed 30,000 visitors in a matter of months.
displayImages.altText: The Powerhouse opened it’s doors to the public earlier this year and has welcomed 30,000 visitors in a matter of months.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Powerhouse opened its doors to the public earlier this year and has welcomed 30,000 visitors in a matter of months.

displayImages.caption: Pictured is a piece by Melbourne-based artist Ape Seven.
displayImages.altText: Pictured is a piece by Melbourne-based artist Ape Seven.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pictured is a piece by Melbourne-based artist Ape Seven.

displayImages.caption: The only rules for artists are that work has to be child-friendly, not offensive and not overly political.
displayImages.altText: The only rules for artists are that work has to be child friendly, not offensive and not overly political.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The only rules for artists are that work has to be child-friendly, not offensive and not overly political.

displayImages.caption: Pictured are Geelong-based artists Gaudin Willett (left) and Brett Fanning (right).
displayImages.altText: Pictured are Geelong-based artists Gaudin Willett (left) and Brett Fanning (right).
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pictured are Geelong-based artists Gaudin Willett (left) and Brett Fanning (right).

displayImages.caption: Fanning (aka Remi) identifies the Powerhouse with freedom. ‘I feel like we now have somewhere to belong,’ he said.
displayImages.altText: Brett Fanning (aka Remi) identifies the Powerhouse with freedom. “I feel like we now have somewhere to belong,” he said.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fanning (aka Remi) identifies the Powerhouse with freedom. ‘I feel like we now have somewhere to belong,’ he said.

displayImages.caption: Street artists make a habit of ‘bombing’ each others’ work. This is a creative corruption by Glummo, but only when viewed from a certain position in the building.
displayImages.altText: Street artists make a habit of ‘bombing’ each others work. This is a creative corruption by Glummo, but only when viewed from a certain position in the building.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Street artists make a habit of ‘bombing’ each others’ work. This is a creative corruption by Glummo, but only when viewed from a certain position in the building.

displayImages.caption: A wide-angle photo showing Glummo’s piece in context.
displayImages.altText: A wide-angle photo showing Glummo’s piece in context.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A wide-angle photo showing Glummo’s piece in context.

displayImages.caption: Connie Waters of Ocean Grove, pictured, puts the finishing touches to her work. She said the area was absolutely crying out for the Powerhouse.
displayImages.altText: Connie Waters of Ocean Grove, pictured, puts the finishing touches to her work. She said the area was absolutely crying out for something like The Powerhouse.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Connie Waters of Ocean Grove, pictured, puts the finishing touches to her work. She said the area was absolutely crying out for the Powerhouse.

displayImages.caption: A residual sign of the Powerhouse’s former purpose.
displayImages.altText: A sign of the Poweshouse’s former purpose.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A residual sign of the Powerhouse’s former purpose.

displayImages.caption: This piece by internationally-renowned street artist Rone, who hails from Geelong himself, dominates the southern end of the structure.
displayImages.altText: This piece by internationally-renowned street artist Rone, who hails from Geelong, dominates the southern end of the structure.
displayImages.cleanCaption: This piece by internationally-renowned street artist Rone, who hails from Geelong himself, dominates the southern end of the structure.

displayImages.caption: The venue features an average of three new artworks every day. Photograph: Stuart Walmsley for the Guardian
